Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit: Plant mitochondrial genomes are surprisingly different from those of animals and fungi. They are also involved in such diverse and important processes as plant growth, flowering and seed set. A significant technological gap in the study of plant physiology and genetics is the inability to transform plant mitochondria. Although it has not been accomplished in the laboratory, horizontal gene transfer between mitochondria of different plant species is evidence that foreign DNA can be incorporated into the mitochondrial genome. A new understanding of recombination mechanisms suggests two novel approaches to the problem: using large homologous regions for targeting, or transforming a mutant defective in recombination homology surveillance. This research will enable new approaches to plant biology and biotechnology that are currently impossible. Three important phases of achieving transformation will be done. These are to engineer the bacterium Agrobacterium tumefaciens to target introduced DNA to mitochondria, to use large regions of homology for recombination targeting, and the choice of selectable markers. This project will use multiple approaches to the selectable marker problem, including both endogenous and exogenous genes.
Broader impacts: This project will have a tremendous impact on the research infrastructure for plant mitochondrial biology. This will dramatically open up the field to new experimental directions and new advances, both for basic biology and in agriculturally important plants. The project will involve an undergraduate research training experience in the summer, and there will be an emphasis on broadening participation. A high school student and teacher training effort at the institution will be incorporated, and the institution also sponsors an undergraduate summer internship program that will be integrated into the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this high-risk, high-reward project was to develop a method for plant mitochondrial transformation. Of the three compartments in the plant cell that contain their own DNA, only the nucleus and the chloroplast can be transformed with exogenous DNA, not the mitochondrion (often referred to as the powerhouse of the cell). This limits the ability to study the genes of the mitochondrion and their regulation. Previous investigators have periodically attempted to accomplish this goal and failed. The best hypotheses for why it has failed fall into three categories: 1) a system for effectively delivering DNA to the mitochondrion in a living plant, 2) effective integration of the delivered DNA into the mitochondrial genome, and 3) a gene that can be used to select plants with transformed mitochondria. We have worked on all three aspects. We modified Agrobacterium so it would deliver DNA to the mitochondria rather than the nucleus. We used exogenous DNA that had large regions of identity to the mitochondrial genome in order to enhance the probability of integration. Finally we experimented with several possible selectable marker genes. The combination of these efforts resulted in apparent transformants, but the transgene was not stable and heritable. One likely explanation for the instability is that Agrobacterium delivers single-stranded DNA, which may not be as suitable for integration into the mitochondrial genome as double-stranded DNA. The award has expired, but possible methods for overcoming this issue are still being considered by the PI.

The broader impacts of this project include contributions to the field and training. There has been a long-standing conundrum in the field of plant mitochondrial biology. Most mitochondrial genomes have very low mutation rates, yet rearrange and expand very rapidly. A unified explanation of both phenomena has been lacking. While examining the Arabidopsis mitochondrial genome, the PI envisioned a mechanism based in DNA damage and repair mechanisms that would resolve this conundrum, and also explain the large quantities of junk DNA that accumulate in plant mitochondria. These observations have resulted in two publications that have contributed to the field of mitochondrial genome dynamics and evolution. With respect to training, one graduate student and ten undergraduates have worked on various aspects of the project. These eleven students include seven women and two underrepresented minorities. The undergraduates who have graduated include two currently in graduate school, one working in a research lab as a technician, one in medical school and one in veterinary medicine school.
